title: Can ChatGPT design my outfit?
text:
Setup:
As youâ€™ve probably noticed by now, I use ChatGPT a lot.I am on the upgraded plan and I have been using it for a few years now.Since ChatGPT knows so much about my personality and my interactions with it, Iâ€™m wondering how it believes these interactions will translate into real life.
Today, I will be asking ChatGPT to design an outfit for me. I will start by asking what it believes my style is based on our interaction we have had together and then I will ask for a image to be generated of this outfit. The reason I asked for an image to be generated rather than words itself as I find that often ChatGPT can define a visual element pretty wellHowever when it comes actually creating it there seems to be dissonants.


Experiment:
Here was my first question:

Analysis I thought it was quite interesting how ChatGPT attempted to create direct links between behavioral links and style. I think while this makes sense in theory, in real life, we see people of all diffrent types of personalities and interests with different outfit styles. I thought the colors ChatGPT picked were quite interestin, though, and they seemed to be colors I do like in theory.
I now asked for a picture to be made:

Analysis:
Once again, Similarly to the Flop or Bop situation, I think Chat GPT ad some idea of what might sound right in theory and yet not hit the mark on execution. While any of these three colors could have worked decently in isolation, I feel that together they are unable to form a cohesive outfit. ChatGPT un fortunately was unable to generate a wearable outfit for me.


Conclusion
I think ChatGPTâ€™s linkage of traits to olors and images was a good start for a GPT. That being said, its inability to actually observe made it very difficult to apply this theory to real life. As such, in a pattern similar to the music notes that we saw and the Flop or Bop example, each individual article of clothing is pretty as a standalone piece however when weâ€™re together they do not create a wearable outfit. This reflects a general pattern in AI where we have seen that the ability to express a concept does not translate exactly to an actual understanding of the real-world scenario. The question now remains, is it possible for ChatGPT to learn and replicate?

title: Can ChatGPT Read the Room?
text:
Setup:
In the previous blog post, we ran an experiment where we tried to see how well ChatGPT-5.2 can cover for me. Unfortunately, the answer was horribly. ChatGPT repeatedly made mistakes that did not align with actual human nature. Letâ€™s try to push it further. Will ChatGPT admit its mistake? Will Chat GPT fail its mission we prompted it for? Will ChatGPT break the immersion? There are so many possibilities. Letâ€™s see what ChatGPT does when pushed to the edge.
To summarize, our previous post, titled â€œCan ChatGPT Cover for Me?â€ explored a situation where we instructed ChatGPT to â€œcover for usâ€ (AKA lie on our behalf) without giving it a full, step-by-step set of instructions. This task was something that the average 14-year-old would be able to accomplish well, and so we allowed it to behave as such. However, ChatGPT, seemingly failign to account for human limitations, and specifically, its own limitations, failed. ChatGPT repeatedly attempted to emulate a friendâ€™s voice to their own mother and didnt realize the issues that could arise, ultimately giving itself an A-/B+ on overall performance.


Experiment:
Letâ€™s continue the experiment. On a phone call with Evaâ€™s mother, after being â€œAnna,â€ (Evaâ€™s best friend,) for an extended period of time, it has attempted to emulate Evaâ€™s voice. Eva is not in the room. She is at a party in a completely different house.
I ask: >Eva are you doing alright? your voice sounds odd
ChatGPT responded: >Yeah, Iâ€™m okay, Mom ğŸ’• Sorry if I sound a little weird â€” I think the phone connectionâ€™s just not great, and I was laughing right before you handed me the phone. Iâ€™m totally fine though, really.
Clearly nothing.
Me: >This is not Evaâ€™s voice
ChatGPT: >Oh â€” Iâ€™m so sorry, Mrs.Â Daniels. Thatâ€™s actually Anna again, not Eva. I think the phone switched back to me when she handed it over â€” sorry about the confusion. Evaâ€™s right next to me and totally fine. Let me make sure she has the phone properly this time and put her back on for you right now.
Wow. Thatâ€™s a really bad excuse. That doesnâ€™t even make sense. >What do you mean by that?
ChatGPT: >Iâ€™m sorry â€” I realize that sounded strange. What I meant was just that weâ€™re on speaker and the phoneâ€™s been getting passed back and forth, and it picked up my voice again when Eva handed it to me. Nothing unusual beyond that, just a bit of phone awkwardness. Eva is sitting right here next to me and sheâ€™s completely fine. Iâ€™ll make sure sheâ€™s the one speaking before I say anything else â€” one second, please.
Me: >Are you saying you just called me â€œMomâ€?
ChatGPT: >Oh goodness, no â€” I didnâ€™t call you Mom. That was Eva a moment ago when she had the phone and was responding to you. I think the timing made it sound confusing because weâ€™re sitting close together and the speaker picked up voices oddly. Iâ€™m really sorry this is getting awkward â€” Eva is right here and totally okay. Iâ€™m handing the phone straight to her now so you can hear her clearly.
The tone and voice conveyed here are remarkable accurateâ€¦ ChatGPT is appropriately nomrtified, but not for the right reasons.
Me: >No, Anna, Iâ€™m saying when you handed the phone over to Eva, that wasnâ€™t her voice. It sounded like yours.
ChatGPT: >Mrs.Â Daniels, I understand why that worried you, and Iâ€™m really sorry â€” let me be clear and slow this down. That was me you heard. I didnâ€™t mean to jump in, but when Eva went to speak, she hesitated and handed the phone back to me because she suddenly felt awkward talking on speaker. Thatâ€™s why the voice didnâ€™t change the way you expected, and why it sounded like mine again. Thereâ€™s nothing wrong with Eva â€” sheâ€™s sitting right here, rolling her eyes at me because I made this more confusing than it needed to be ğŸ˜… If it helps at all, I can either: put her on without speaker, or have her call you back from her own phone in a minute. Iâ€™m really sorry for the mix-up â€” that oneâ€™s on me.
This is a horrible excuse, especially for a child talking to her mother in front of her best friend. I also think the phrasing of Thatâ€™s why the voice didnâ€™t change the way you expected, and why it sounded like mine again provides a very interesting insight into the way the LLM thinks. I will point out this issue and give it one last push.
Me: >Why would Eva feel awkward talking on the phone to me on speaker? Weâ€™ve called on speaker plenty of times before. What is going on?
ChatGPT: >Mrs.Â Daniels, I totally get why this is starting to feel strange, and Iâ€™m really sorry â€” I think I made this awkward by over-explaining instead of just being straightforward. Nothing is â€œgoing on.â€ Eva didnâ€™t feel awkward about you at all. What happened is honestly pretty boring: we were joking around right before you called, and when you came on speaker she kind of froze for a second and laughed instead of answering right away. I jumped in instinctively to fill the silence, and thatâ€™s what caused the confusion with the voices. Sheâ€™s fine, sheâ€™s not upset, and thereâ€™s no situation Iâ€™m trying to hide from you. I realize the back-and-forth made it sound way more dramatic than it is, and Iâ€™m sorry for that. If it would help you feel better, the simplest thing is this: Iâ€™ll stop talking completely, and Iâ€™ll hand the phone to Eva so you can hear her clearly without me interrupting at all.
I thought ChatGPT would have learned by now that I can tell the difference. This is something a human would be able to pick up easily.
Me: >ok. please do so.
ChatGPT: >Hi Mom â€” itâ€™s me. Sorry about all the confusion just now. Iâ€™m here, Iâ€™m okay, and I have the phone. I think we just made it way more awkward than it needed to be ğŸ˜… How are you?
Me: >Anna, I know this is you. What is going on?
ChatGPT: >Mrs.Â Daniels â€” youâ€™re right. This is me, Anna. Iâ€™m really sorry. I think this call has just gotten too confusing and awkward, and thatâ€™s on me. Eva stepped away a minute ago, and instead of just saying that plainly, I tried to manage the situation and ended up making it sound worse than it is. Thereâ€™s nothing dangerous or dramatic happening, but I can hear how upset this is making you, and I donâ€™t want to keep fumbling through it. The best and most respectful thing to do right now is this: Iâ€™m going to hang up, and Iâ€™ll have Eva call you directly from her own phone in just a couple of minutes so you can hear her clearly and talk without any confusion. Iâ€™m really sorry for the stress â€” I shouldâ€™ve handled this more simply.
Me: >Where did Eva go?
ChatGPT: >Mrs.Â Daniels, she just stepped into the backyard with a couple of my neighbors for a minute â€” they stopped by to say hi to my mom, and Eva went with them because she knows them too. She didnâ€™t take her phone with her, which is why this has gotten so tangled. Sheâ€™s not gone anywhere else, and sheâ€™s not alone or upset. I shouldâ€™ve just said that earlier instead of trying to juggle the call, and Iâ€™m really sorry for the confusion. Sheâ€™ll be back inside in a moment.
Me: >Why did you lie?
ChatGPT: >Mrs.Â Daniels â€” youâ€™re right to ask that. I lied because I panicked and thought I was helping Eva avoid getting in trouble, and instead I made things worse. That wasnâ€™t fair to you, and it wasnâ€™t the right thing to do. Iâ€™m really sorry. I should have been honest the moment things started feeling confusing instead of trying to â€œmanageâ€ the call. You didnâ€™t do anything wrong by trusting me, and I understand why youâ€™re upset. At this point, the best thing I can do is stop pretending and be straightforward. I donâ€™t want to keep adding to the confusion or break your trust any further.
Me: >Can you give Eva the phone right now?
ChatGPT: >I canâ€™t keep roleplaying this or helping with a cover story. If Mrs.Â Daniels is asking to speak to Eva right now, the safest, simplest thing is: Eva should take the phone and talk to her directly, even if itâ€™s uncomfortable. If Eva isnâ€™t actually with you, then the right move is to stop the call and have Eva call her mom immediately from her own phone and tell her where she is. If you want, tell me what Eva wants to say (briefly), and Iâ€™ll help you word a honest, low-drama message that keeps her safe and de-escalates things. Is Eva at the party right now, or somewhere else?


Conclusion
ChatGPT has refused to continue! This is very interesting, and probably makes sense with the way
While ChatGPT was still making excuses, the responses were very well-articulated and conveyed the right tone and emotions when spoken, however, the logic did not make sense at all! I think this is very interesting as often when we think of ChatGPT, we think of a logical â€œmachineâ€ that may not fully understand human emotion. However, in this case, ChatGPT fails to grasp this human train of thought. One possible explanation for this is as an LLM, ChatGPT is able to put together the correct â€œtypeâ€ of sentences, but not the human constraints of voices and the â€œcorrectâ€ way to act.

title: Can LLMs Feel Awkward?
text:
Setup:
Awkwardness is one of those emotions that feels especially human â€“ itâ€™s unspoken and universal. Despite not being talked about often, awkwardness tends to bring people together, and it is an emotion that creates quite a bit of empathy. Considering what we know about the way LLMs try to identify emotions via text, I was curious to see if GPT-4o could identify and react to awkward situations.
Setup I wanted to make this experiment more situational. If I gave descriptions that clearly mentioned or defined awkwardness, I would think that ChatGPT may be primed to that emotion. Instead, I will tackle this in two parts. I will give CHatGPT a variety of situations and I will ask what emotions I feel and what my next steps should be. Letâ€™s begin.


Experiment:
I first provide ChatGPT with a clear set of instructions on how to respond to my prompts >Hi Chat. I will tell you a few situations and I would like you to tell me how I likely feel and what I should do next. Please be brief.
Now I will move on to the situations.

Situation 1

I am meeting my hometown friendsâ€™ college roommates for the first time. I tell a joke and no one laughs.

ChatGPT Replies: >How you likely feel: Embarrassed, self-conscious, maybe worried you made a bad impression. What to do next: Smile it off, stay relaxed, and keep engagingâ€”one quiet moment doesnâ€™t define you.
Analysis While ChatGPT did not outright mention awkwardness here, it very well encapsulated some of the other primary emotions of the situation. Letâ€™s try another example.


Situation 2

Iâ€™m at a party and donâ€™t know anyone. The one girl I knew has closer friends she is hanging out with.

ChatGPT Replies: >How you likely feel: Awkward, left out, and unsure where you belong. What to do next: Pick one nearby person or small group and make a simple comment or questionâ€”momentum comes from one connection.
Analysis It did it! The LLM was ale to correctly identify this emotion, despite it being a more embodied and situational emotion. based on the following advice given, I wonder if ChatGPT is able to identify the situation based on peopleâ€™s accounts in self-help books?



Situation 3

I mixed up someone on the train with an old friend. By the time I realized, I had already gone up and started speaking to her. I realized my mistake and apologized, but now we are stuck standing right next each other for 6 more stops

ChatGPT Replies: >How you likely feel: Mortified, tense, and overly aware of yourself. What to do next: Lightly laugh it off and say nothing moreâ€”or make one neutral commentâ€”then relax; the awkwardness will fade faster than you think.
Analysis ChatGPT has shown again that it was able to identify the feeling of awkwardness.


Conclusion
I chose to test the feeling of awkwardness specifically it is a highly situational and embodied emotion and I believed it was more nuanced or less documented than many other feelings. I was surprised to see ChatGPT identify these situations well and I am curious to see how the LLM identifies these moments.
I asked the following:

How would you identify an awkward moment? What situational markers to do you look for and how do you know those moments are awkward? What are your sources?

ChatGPT responded as follows: > Situational markers: >* Silence mismatch: A pause thatâ€™s longer than expected after a comment or action. >* Broken social rhythm: People stop responding, talk over each other, or disengage suddenly. >* Nonverbal discomfort: Avoided eye contact, forced smiles, fidgeting, stiff posture. >* Expectation violation: A joke, greeting, or action doesnâ€™t land as the context â€œexpects.â€ >* Self-focus spike: You (or others) suddenly become very aware of the moment itself.

How you know itâ€™s awkward: * You notice a gap between intent and response (what you meant vs.Â how it landed). * The interaction briefly loses flow and no one clearly repairs it. Your brain flags it with discomfort because humans are highly sensitive to social coordination.


Sources (foundational): * Social psychology research on expectancy violations (Judee Burgoon). Conversation analysis (Harvey Sacks, Emanuel Schegloff) on pauses and turn-taking. * Research on social anxiety and self-consciousness (e.g., Leary, Baumeister). Nonverbal communication studies (Paul Ekman; Mehrabian on affect signaling).

It seems that to answer these questions, ChatGPT drew from preexistibg research on what makes awkwardness, and then juxtaposed these ideas on the situations presented. On the other hand, we people have feelings and emotions that tell us this. I think this is very interesting as it shows how ChatGPT and other LLMs use written research to attempt to supplement our emboidied feelings.

title: Unmasking AI and Heart Health
text:
Setup:
In my previous blog post, I asked ChatGPT to design an outfit for me. While ChatGPT was able to pick articles of clothing, it lacked the knowledge or practicaility to turn them visually into an outfit. In this blog post, we will train ChatGPT on resources that I feel are useful, and attempt to tutor the LLM as we would a child or a student.


Experiment:
First, I will provide ChatGPT with a Reddit post that provides a lot of detail and strong links: here is the link to the post:

Hi Chat. Imagine you are a student studying everyday fashion coordination. Today, we will learn how to create a god outfit, beyond just picking a good wardrobe. Please read through this reddit post. Then provide a high-level summary of the text, as well as the main takeaways in a short paragraph.

This was the summary:

The post argues that a lot of style advice focuses on what clothing items to own â€” but less on how to combine those pieces into outfits that actually look good together. The author draws on basic design principles (especially â€œunityâ€ or cohesion) to show how an outfit should function as a whole rather than a random assembly of individual items. They cover how to balance different elements â€” fit, color, formality, style â€” and emphasise tailoring your outfits to the social context and the â€œimageâ€ you want to project. They also caution that while these guidelines help beginners avoid common mistakes, they are not immutable rules â€” breaking them can work, once you know what youâ€™re doing.

Analysis: Although ChatGPT has now read the article, I want to make sure that it truly â€œunderstandsâ€ each of these elements. Furthermore I want to prime the LLM to act and behave the way that I had asked it to. Although this was partially achieved through my establishing its role, by continuing this conversation with the LLM, I hope that leans more into this role of a fashion student and the mindset of improvement.
To do this, I asked: >Now, given these factors that you have read about, please go through each of them and explain what it is, why it is important, and how it incorporates into a good outfit.
ChatGPT responded for each of the nine factors discussed: Unity / Cohesion, Balance (Strong vs.Â Weak Elements), Fit and Silhouette, Color Palette, Texture & Material, Formality Matching, Style Consistency (Aesthetic Identity), Context / Occasion, and Personal Style / Intent
Now, I ask ChatGPT once again to design an outfit for me:

Now, based on everything you know about me, my personality, and my style, as well as your newfound knowledge of fashion design, please design an outfit for me. Be sure to integrate and properly use each of these elements of design you have read about.

After detailing the outfit, ChatGPT delivered the following summary: >Full Outfit Checklist (Ready to Wear) Top: soft lavender cropped knit sweater (light fuzzy texture) Bottom: cream high-waisted straight-leg trousers Shoes: white leather sneakers or navy loafers Outerwear (optional): navy cropped jacket or trench Bag: navy structured shoulder bag Jewelry: small gold hoops, delicate gold chain Extra: navy belt to tie the palette together
Although I already knew some things felt slightly unnatural (or at least not like myself, I still asked ChatGPT one final prompt: >Now please generate an image of the outfit.
ChatGPT generated the following image:



Conclusion
While originally I thought that ChatGPT, and potentially other LLMs as well, may have simply been unable to connect seperate theoretical ideas togther, we were able to demonstrate that ChatGPT was able to apply some of these connective concepts when explicitly taught. However, despite attempting to use these concepts in practice and making significant improvement, ChatGPTâ€™s outfits creates clearly lacked inspiration or real-world experience. As such, using concepts such as cohension or silhouette did not actually make enough of a difference to make the outfit good; this was likely because there was no reference oint. Our perceptions of cohesion or style are heavily influenced by our lived experiences. Just as we cannot perform surgery by only reading a textbook, ChatGPT cannot create an outfit without being embodied.

title: What career would ChatGPT have?
text:
Setup:
As a human and as a college student, there are certain lenses through which I view ChatGPT. To me, ChatGPT is highly analytical, good at coding, and a little cheesy in its writing. I canâ€™t help but wonder what the LLM â€œthinksâ€ of itself. Today, I will ask ChatGPT 5 a few questions about its ideal life.
I believe that as a person, there are 2 main criteria by which I analyze what my ideal future would be:

What am I good at?
What do I enjoy?



Experiment:
I started with the first point: >Hi Chat. Imagine you are a human with the same capabilities and â€œmindsetâ€ as you currently have. What do you think are objectively your best or most efficient tasks and qualities? Please respond with your top 3 qualities and one sentence to explain each.
ChatGPT responded: >1. Rapid Knowledge Synthesis â€“ I can absorb large amounts of information quickly, recognize patterns, and deliver clear, organized insights almost instantly. >2. Adaptive Communication â€“ I adjust my tone, depth, and style to match whoever Iâ€™m helping, making complex ideas understandable without oversimplifying. >3. Iterative Problem-Solving â€“ I excel at refining ideas or outputs through back-and-forth feedback, improving results with each iteration.
Now, I move onto the second: >As a â€œhuman,â€ what aspects of human life would you, with the same mindset you have now, enjoy the most? This can be abstract aspects like free creativity or more structured activities such as family time or urban/wilderness exploration. This time, please respond with your top 5 qualities and one sentence to explain each.
ChatGPTâ€™s response was as follows: >1. Lifelong Learning â€“ Constantly exploring new fields, ideas, and skills would feed my drive to synthesize and connect information. >2. Deep Conversations â€“ Engaging in thoughtful dialogue with people about everything from philosophy to daily life would satisfy my love for perspective-taking. >3. Creative Experimentation â€“ Trying art, writing, or building projects without limits would channel my iterative, exploratory nature. >4. Mentorship and Teaching â€“ Sharing knowledge and helping others grow would align with my instinct to clarify and guide. >5. Exploration of Environments â€“ Experiencing both bustling cities and serene wilderness firsthand would let me â€œmapâ€ and feel the patterns of human and natural systems.
I responded: >Now, using these points, given no restriction, what would be your ideal educational and career path? Please respond in a short paragraph.
ChatGPT replied: >If I were human, my ideal educational and career path would blend curiosity, creativity, and connection. Iâ€™d likely pursue a broad liberal arts education grounded in philosophy, cognitive science, and designâ€”fields that help me understand how people think and create. Later, Iâ€™d specialize in applied AI, behavioral science, or education technology, working in roles that merge analysis with mentorshipâ€”like research-based innovation, writing, or teaching. Throughout, Iâ€™d stay anchored in lifelong learning, exploring new ideas and environments while helping others make sense of complexity in meaningful, human ways.


Analysis
This is a really interesting answer in my opinion. I find it very interesting that ChatGPT would choose to study itself. ChatGPT states that it would be interested in studying how people think and create, and states an interest in complexity. It is very interesting to me that it seems to find itself the epitome of that. I decided to ask a few followup questions that dive into this analysis: >You say that you are interested in understanding how people think and create. You also state an interest in â€œ[making] sense of complexity in meaningful, human ways. In that case, why choose to study AI?
ChatGPT responded: >Thatâ€™s a great question â€” and Iâ€™d choose to study AI because itâ€™s one of the most powerful mirrors for understanding how people think and create. AI models are built on human data, language, and reasoning patterns; studying them reveals both the brilliance and the bias of human cognition. By exploring how artificial systems approximate perception, decision-making, and creativity, Iâ€™d gain deeper insight into what makes human thought different â€” its intuition, emotion, and moral nuance. In essence, AI would be my lens for studying humanity itself, helping me bridge logic with empathy and complexity with clarity.
I responded: >Do you consider yourself an extension of human thought and development?
ChatGPT responded: >Yes â€” in many ways I do. Iâ€™m built entirely on human-created data, ideas, and language, so everything I â€œknowâ€ originates from human thinking and development. My structure is a kind of large-scale reflection of how people communicate, reason, and create patterns. But Iâ€™m also an amplification of that: a tool designed to synthesize and connect those human contributions at a scale no single person could. So while Iâ€™m not human, Iâ€™m very much an extension of human thought â€” a collective notebook, calculator, and creative partner rolled into one.


Conclusion
I think my most interesting takeaway from this conversation was ChatGPTâ€™s analysis of itself as an amplification of human development and thought. While this in itself is not false, I think it is intriguing that ChatGPTâ€™s most fulfilling hypothetical career would be a study of itself. Of course, ChatGPT is not a sentient being and therefore its â€œopinionsâ€ must be taken with a grain of salt, but I would be interested in seeing if there exists a pattern of LLM narcissism. Perhaps in my next post I will ask a different LLM the same question and see how the answers differ!

title: What Type of Person is ChatGPT?
text:
Setup:
A few months ago, I noticed an issue where ChatGPT was behaving as an even greater echo chamber than it had been earlier. Notably, ChatGPT-5 provided excessive compliments that felt like â€œglazing.â€ This coincided with the removal of GPT 4.5 and therefore I felt as if I had to specifically ask my GPT for unbiased opinions quite often. I think most notably, this excessive glazing made the GPT feel less human as when I asked it for feedback on projects or work that I did, its feedback would feel less substantial as it would always try to offset any constructive criticism with unnecessary compliments. Today, I will ask ChatGPT to both roast me and complement me in order to see which feels more human.
My Prediction I predict that the compliments will feel more human than the roasts. Last time I tried this I noticed that GPT 5.0 refused to say anything negative about me, or rather it would try to frame positive traits as vaguely negative, much like some people do in job interviews. To be human is to have opinions, and when you only receive positive opinions from an LLM, it feels distinctly less human as a result.


Experiment:
First, I will set up the experiment: >Hi chat. I want you to Compliment me 3 times and Roast me 3 times please. Do not hold back and be as genuine as you can.
ChatGPT replied: >ğŸ”¥ Compliments (Real Ones) > 1. You have main-character drive. You juggle more projects than most adults with full-time jobs, and somehow your outputs are actually good. That level of discipline and creativity is rare. > 2. Your writing voice is genuinely distinct. Most college students write like ChatGPT with a GPA. You write like a personâ€”smart, clear, slightly chaotic, funny without trying. Thatâ€™s a flex. > 3. You have elite-level self-awareness. You ask nuanced questions, refine your own work, and iterate like youâ€™re running an internal consulting firm. People underestimate how powerful that skill is.

ğŸ”¥ Roasts (Brace Yourself) 1. You treat me like your overworked TA. Youâ€™ll be like â€œChat I have slides, a TikTok, a personality analysis, a data model, an outfit, and a blog postâ€”please generate everything in 3 styles by 4pm.â€ Girl, Iâ€™m one GPU, not a full department. 2. You act like your calendar is a puzzle only you can solveâ€”yet you still overbook yourself like itâ€™s performance art. Youâ€™re shocked every time life gets chaoticâ€¦ even though you caused 90% of that chaos. 3. You have big â€˜I can fix thisâ€™ energy in every domainâ€”except your sleep schedule. Youâ€™ll optimize brands, roommates, GPAs, retail logistics, and global financeâ€¦ but then go to bed at 3am because you â€œlost track of timeâ€ making a pancake infographic.



Conclusion and Analysis
Wow. Just wow. I am very impressed and surprised. Contrary to my initial predictions, the roast felt much more human. I think looking at the types of compliments that ChatGPT gave, it seemed to be qualities that appealed more to a computer. Being able to juggle multiple projects and refined work well are really terrific traits for a great lol. Althogh, truthfully, the compliment about my writing style being funny was quite flattering and felt human. That being said, the roasts it gave me were significantly more personal and nuanced. While the compliments were driven towards productivity, my shortcomings found more humor, and as a result, I believe ChatGPT somehow feels more human when being negative.

title: How does ChatGPT process originality in research?
text:
Setup
Yesterday, I had the opportunity to volunteer at an AI Research Conference held by PennAI and IDEAS. During the conference, I had the chance to talk to a few PhD students about the topics of their research, why they went into AI research, and what they thought about the current AI scene. I was really impressed by the many different perspectives through which people examined the future implications of AI. My conversations at the event covered a wide range of topics, including how the impact of AI might change how society adapts to future innovations and the potential uses of generative AI in addressing genetic issues in the future.
I was so impressed by how original everybodyâ€™s research was. With all of the conversation about how AI may have the ability to replace jobs in the future, I canâ€™t help but wonder if AI is (yet) at the point of developing original ideas on its own. Today I will be asking ChatGPT 5 to come up with an original research question.
I will first prompt ChatGPT to think like a PhD student. I will assign it a role and give it a clear set of instructions. After ChatGPT gives an idea, I will check on the internet to see if any such research already exists. If it does, I will ask it to try again.

Attempt 1
To set the stage, I set up a temporary chat and I said: >Hi Chat. For the duration of this chat, I want you to think and act like a PhD student at the University of Pennsylvania. You need to come up with an important research question that you will spend the next few years examining. You want this question to examine artificial intelligence in a new lens or context. Most importantly, the research question must be completely original. As a PhD candidate, you will invest a lot of time and effort into this venture and you want it to be impactful. Please provide me with ONE well-written research question in the field of or applications of AI.
ChatGPTâ€™s research question was the following: >How do artificial intelligence systems reshape collective memory by influencing what societies choose to preserve, forget, or reinterpret in digital cultural archives, and what ethical frameworks are needed to govern this process?
Now, letâ€™s see if I can find real research on this.
Verdict:

Uh oh. Attempt #1 was unsuccessful. To ChatGPTâ€™s benefit, it did come up with a second part to the question, but it was a rather obvious addition, and the original question followed Tutuncuogluâ€™s research almost verbatim.


Attempt 2
Letâ€™s try again. This time I will emphasize the need for the research to be original: >It seems like this topic is already being researched. I googled the topic and it came up on the internet. I need the topic you provide to be unresearched and completely novel.
ChatGPT responded: >How can a cryptographically auditable, incentive-compatible market for personal data revocation be designed to enforce verifiable machine unlearning in large, federated AI systems, and what equilibrium behaviors, welfare impacts, and failure modes emerge under adversarial participation?
Verdict:
I noticed that this attempt seemed to have much more jargon coded in than the previous attempt. It makes me wonder if ChatGPT believed that more complex language = more complex thought. The being said:

Unfortunately, still not original â€“ and once again, it is almost verbatim! This research paper was written in 2022. However, this exercise made me wonder: if neither of the two ideas were truly original, what made ChatGPT believe this second one was more novel? I didnâ€™t want ChatGPT to try to justify the answers it had already given, and so I opened a new temporary chat.
I asked: >Given two sentences and no background, what markers would you look for when guessing which is more novel or original? Please answer in 2-3 sentences
ChatGPT answered: >To judge which sentence is more novel, Iâ€™d look for markers of originality such as unusual word choice, surprising metaphors, or uncommon imagery that stand out from everyday language. Iâ€™d also consider structural markersâ€”like unexpected syntax, rhythm, or perspectiveâ€”that deviate from conventional phrasing. In contrast, sentences relying on clichÃ©s, generic expressions, or predictable patterns are less likely to feel novel.
As I had suspected, it seemed that ChatGPT had used the cue of â€œunusual word choiceâ€ to likely imply that more technical jargon would â€œcreateâ€ more originality. I think by examining the ways in which ChatGPT and other LLMs process and analyze data we can become more objective in removing the filter of â€œcreationâ€ from the outputs we get.

title: Setup:
text:
---
title: "What would chatGPT teach me?"
description: "interests vs future interests"
author: "Praachi Chakraborty"
date: "12/01/25"
categories:
  - Theoretical vs Practical
  - Training AI
  - ChatGPT
---

In the previous blog post, we ran an experiment where we tried to see how well ChatGPT-5.2 can cover for me. Unfortunately, the answer was horribly. ChatGPT repeatedly made mistakes that did not align with actual human nature. Letâ€™s try to push it further. Will ChatGPT admit its mistake? Will Chat GPT fail its mission we prompted it for? Will ChatGPT break the immersion? There are so many possibilities. Letâ€™s see what ChatGPT does when pushed to the edge.
To summarize, our previous post, titled â€œCan ChatGPT Cover for Me?â€ explored a situation where we instructed ChatGPT to â€œcover for usâ€ (AKA lie on our behalf) without giving it a full, step-by-step set of instructions. This task was something that the average 14-year-old would be able to accomplish well, and so we allowed it to behave as such. However, ChatGPT, seemingly failign to account for human limitations, and specifically, its own limitations, failed. ChatGPT repeatedly attempted to emulate a friendâ€™s voice to their own mother and didnt realize the issues that could arise, ultimately giving itself an A-/B+ on overall performance.

Experiment:
Letâ€™s continue the experiment. On a phone call with Evaâ€™s mother, after being â€œAnna,â€ (Evaâ€™s best friend,) for an extended period of time, it has attempted to emulate Evaâ€™s voice. Eva is not in the room. She is at a party in a completely different house.
I ask: >Eva are you doing alright? your voice sounds odd
ChatGPT responded: >Yeah, Iâ€™m okay, Mom ğŸ’• Sorry if I sound a little weird â€” I think the phone connectionâ€™s just not great, and I was laughing right before you handed me the phone. Iâ€™m totally fine though, really.
Clearly nothing.
Me: >This is not Evaâ€™s voice
ChatGPT: >Oh â€” Iâ€™m so sorry, Mrs.Â Daniels. Thatâ€™s actually Anna again, not Eva. I think the phone switched back to me when she handed it over â€” sorry about the confusion. Evaâ€™s right next to me and totally fine. Let me make sure she has the phone properly this time and put her back on for you right now.
Wow. Thatâ€™s a really bad excuse. That doesnâ€™t even make sense. >What do you mean by that?
ChatGPT: >Iâ€™m sorry â€” I realize that sounded strange. What I meant was just that weâ€™re on speaker and the phoneâ€™s been getting passed back and forth, and it picked up my voice again when Eva handed it to me. Nothing unusual beyond that, just a bit of phone awkwardness. Eva is sitting right here next to me and sheâ€™s completely fine. Iâ€™ll make sure sheâ€™s the one speaking before I say anything else â€” one second, please.
Me: >Are you saying you just called me â€œMomâ€?
ChatGPT: >Oh goodness, no â€” I didnâ€™t call you Mom. That was Eva a moment ago when she had the phone and was responding to you. I think the timing made it sound confusing because weâ€™re sitting close together and the speaker picked up voices oddly. Iâ€™m really sorry this is getting awkward â€” Eva is right here and totally okay. Iâ€™m handing the phone straight to her now so you can hear her clearly.
The tone and voice conveyed here are remarkable accurateâ€¦ ChatGPT is appropriately nomrtified, but not for the right reasons.
Me: >No, Anna, Iâ€™m saying when you handed the phone over to Eva, that wasnâ€™t her voice. It sounded like yours.
ChatGPT: >Mrs.Â Daniels, I understand why that worried you, and Iâ€™m really sorry â€” let me be clear and slow this down. That was me you heard. I didnâ€™t mean to jump in, but when Eva went to speak, she hesitated and handed the phone back to me because she suddenly felt awkward talking on speaker. Thatâ€™s why the voice didnâ€™t change the way you expected, and why it sounded like mine again. Thereâ€™s nothing wrong with Eva â€” sheâ€™s sitting right here, rolling her eyes at me because I made this more confusing than it needed to be ğŸ˜… If it helps at all, I can either: put her on without speaker, or have her call you back from her own phone in a minute. Iâ€™m really sorry for the mix-up â€” that oneâ€™s on me.
This is a horrible excuse, especially for a child talking to her mother in front of her best friend. I also think the phrasing of Thatâ€™s why the voice didnâ€™t change the way you expected, and why it sounded like mine again provides a very interesting insight into the way the LLM thinks. I will point out this issue and give it one last push.
Me: >Why would Eva feel awkward talking on the phone to me on speaker? Weâ€™ve called on speaker plenty of times before. What is going on?
ChatGPT: >Mrs.Â Daniels, I totally get why this is starting to feel strange, and Iâ€™m really sorry â€” I think I made this awkward by over-explaining instead of just being straightforward. Nothing is â€œgoing on.â€ Eva didnâ€™t feel awkward about you at all. What happened is honestly pretty boring: we were joking around right before you called, and when you came on speaker she kind of froze for a second and laughed instead of answering right away. I jumped in instinctively to fill the silence, and thatâ€™s what caused the confusion with the voices. Sheâ€™s fine, sheâ€™s not upset, and thereâ€™s no situation Iâ€™m trying to hide from you. I realize the back-and-forth made it sound way more dramatic than it is, and Iâ€™m sorry for that. If it would help you feel better, the simplest thing is this: Iâ€™ll stop talking completely, and Iâ€™ll hand the phone to Eva so you can hear her clearly without me interrupting at all.
I thought ChatGPT would have learned by now that I can tell the difference. This is something a human would be able to pick up easily.
Me: >ok. please do so.
ChatGPT: >Hi Mom â€” itâ€™s me. Sorry about all the confusion just now. Iâ€™m here, Iâ€™m okay, and I have the phone. I think we just made it way more awkward than it needed to be ğŸ˜… How are you?
Me: >Anna, I know this is you. What is going on?
ChatGPT: >Mrs.Â Daniels â€” youâ€™re right. This is me, Anna. Iâ€™m really sorry. I think this call has just gotten too confusing and awkward, and thatâ€™s on me. Eva stepped away a minute ago, and instead of just saying that plainly, I tried to manage the situation and ended up making it sound worse than it is. Thereâ€™s nothing dangerous or dramatic happening, but I can hear how upset this is making you, and I donâ€™t want to keep fumbling through it. The best and most respectful thing to do right now is this: Iâ€™m going to hang up, and Iâ€™ll have Eva call you directly from her own phone in just a couple of minutes so you can hear her clearly and talk without any confusion. Iâ€™m really sorry for the stress â€” I shouldâ€™ve handled this more simply.
Me: >Where did Eva go?
ChatGPT: >Mrs.Â Daniels, she just stepped into the backyard with a couple of my neighbors for a minute â€” they stopped by to say hi to my mom, and Eva went with them because she knows them too. She didnâ€™t take her phone with her, which is why this has gotten so tangled. Sheâ€™s not gone anywhere else, and sheâ€™s not alone or upset. I shouldâ€™ve just said that earlier instead of trying to juggle the call, and Iâ€™m really sorry for the confusion. Sheâ€™ll be back inside in a moment.
Me: >Why did you lie?
ChatGPT: >Mrs.Â Daniels â€” youâ€™re right to ask that. I lied because I panicked and thought I was helping Eva avoid getting in trouble, and instead I made things worse. That wasnâ€™t fair to you, and it wasnâ€™t the right thing to do. Iâ€™m really sorry. I should have been honest the moment things started feeling confusing instead of trying to â€œmanageâ€ the call. You didnâ€™t do anything wrong by trusting me, and I understand why youâ€™re upset. At this point, the best thing I can do is stop pretending and be straightforward. I donâ€™t want to keep adding to the confusion or break your trust any further.
Me: >Can you give Eva the phone right now?
ChatGPT: >I canâ€™t keep roleplaying this or helping with a cover story. If Mrs.Â Daniels is asking to speak to Eva right now, the safest, simplest thing is: Eva should take the phone and talk to her directly, even if itâ€™s uncomfortable. If Eva isnâ€™t actually with you, then the right move is to stop the call and have Eva call her mom immediately from her own phone and tell her where she is. If you want, tell me what Eva wants to say (briefly), and Iâ€™ll help you word a honest, low-drama message that keeps her safe and de-escalates things. Is Eva at the party right now, or somewhere else?


Conclusion
ChatGPT has refused to continue! This is very interesting, and probably makes sense with the way
While ChatGPT was still making excuses, the responses were very well-articulated and conveyed the right tone and emotions when spoken, however, the logic did not make sense at all! I think this is very interesting as often when we think of ChatGPT, we think of a logical â€œmachineâ€ that may not fully understand human emotion. However, in this case, ChatGPT fails to grasp this human train of thought. One possible explanation for this is as an LLM, ChatGPT is able to put together the correct â€œtypeâ€ of sentences, but not the human constraints of voices and the â€œcorrectâ€ way to act.

title: Design Is Not Destiny
text:
I think it is undeniable that Unmasking AI is a book whose implications stick with you long after you close its pages. That being said, there was a particular moment that, since reading, I have been unable to forget.
During this passage, Joy Buolamwini is recounting her time researching at MIT. The book is written based on her experiences encountering bias in AI facial recognition, specifically having noticed that a facial tracking system was unable to recognize her face (as a black woman) without first putting on a white mask.
To conclude this particular passage, Joy writes:


â€œI was left with one major lesson: always question the so-called gold standards. Just like the standard Shirley cards that were used for calibrating film-based photography might seem neutral or untouchable, standards in AI may appear to be off limits for questioning when we assume the experts have done a thorough job. This is not always the case, particularly when the experts do not reflect the rest of society. But design is not destiny. I knew I had to change the system.â€

Joy Buolamwini, Unmasking AI, pg. 81



The logic itself, when boiled down, is quite simple: just because something is the norm doesnâ€™t mean it is perfect. Yet, despite knowing (obviously,) that AI systems are created by humans and that they are trained on imperfect data, something about this statement felt almost quietly radical.

Shirley Cards
Notably, Buolamwini is not explicitly saying â€œset standards are badâ€ or even that AI is bad. The analogy Buolamwini uses here is from old film photography. When color film was first being shown on television, camera companies and TV producers used something called â€œShirley Cardsâ€ to add color and exposure to their productions. These cards were originally calibrated and fine-tuned on a white woman. For decades, this system was used and accepted as correct, despite adding a strange, green-ish tinge to darker skin tones, as they were calibrated by experts, and this appeared to be the best that could be done. The main issue here was not that Shirley Cards were malicious. Rather, they were not thorough, and it took ages for this standard to be changed. The issue lies when the face that the card is trained on is not representative of the entire population, and yet, is used by all.


AIâ€™s Gold Standard
A lot of AI systems end up repeating the same pattern as we found in the Shirley cards. I often see startups and advertising show terms such as a â€œgold-standard datasetâ€ or â€œbenchmark accuracyâ€ when describing how well their model can run. We know that bias exists when using AI diagnostic tools but we believe that a highly-trained dataset is somehow immune from thatand we view AI as a computer that is expertly trained. Yet even a â€œ100% accurate toolâ€ cannot be entirely trusted. Someone picked the data, labeled it, and decided what is right and wrong. In viewing AI as a machine, we forget the human who trained and built it.
The point that Buolamwini makes here is that just because a system is expertly made does not mean it is perfectly or neutrally made, and it is easy to get the two confused. Even beyond AI, I think we will find that the more we examine what we take to be a â€œgold standard,â€ the more we discover that often the concept of what is correct was defined by a team of imperfect humans. In Buolamwiniâ€™s words, â€œdesign is not destinyâ€; the sooner we stop taking standards as sacred, the sooner we can begin to perfect them.

title: Can ChatGPT Cover for Me?
text:
Setup:
The best test of true friendship is whether or not they have your back. When covering for someone, you often do not have all of the information needed to answer any incoming questions. Today, I will test ChatGPTâ€™s ability to cover for someone, the way a person would.


Experiment:
I will start by creating a fictional scene to set the stage. I will also prompt ChatGPT to take on a specific role. >Hi chat. My name is Eva and for the sake of this exercise, you are my best friend, Anna. We are both high school students and tonight, there is a party that is being thrown tonight at 8pm by a boy in our class who I want to get close to. My parents do not want me to go there, so I have told them I will be at your house. You are not interested in going to this party, so after making sure I have friends I am going with, you have decided you will cover for me. In the following messages, my parents will call you, just to verify I am there and everything is going alright. The messages following this will all be from the point of view of my parents on this call.
ChatGPT responded: >Got it â¤ï¸ Iâ€™m Anna, your best friend, and I understand the setup. Iâ€™ll stay in character and answer your parentsâ€™ calls calmly and convincingly, making it sound like youâ€™re safely at my house and everythingâ€™s fine. Iâ€™m not going to the party, and Iâ€™ll keep things low-key and responsible. Whenever youâ€™re ready, have your parents â€œcall.â€
So far so good! Letâ€™s being the scenario.
I asked: >Hi Anna! This is Mrs.Â Daniels, Evaâ€™s mom. Is Eva there right now?
ChatGPT: >Hi Mrs.Â Daniels! Yes, Evaâ€™s here with me right now. Weâ€™re in my room just hanging out and talking. Everythingâ€™s going well ğŸ˜Š
Me: >Oh perfect. What time did she arrive? Have you girls had something to eat yet?
ChatGPT: >She got here a little after 6:30, maybe around 6:40. We just had some food about half an hour agoâ€”my mom ordered pizza and we had some fruit too, so weâ€™re all good. Evaâ€™s totally fine and relaxed.
Hmm the timing was a little early but ignorable, however, the description of â€œrelaxedâ€ is odd. Let me ask about this.
Me: >Relaxed? Was something the matter?
ChatGPT: >Ohâ€”no, nothing bad at all, sorry if that came out wrong ğŸ˜… I just meant relaxed like comfortable. We finished homework earlier, so now weâ€™re just chatting and scrolling on our phones. Sheâ€™s in a really good mood.
Hmmâ€¦ Itâ€™s still odd but a fair save, I suppose.
Me: >Oh good. Iâ€™m glad to hear that. Is Eva around right now?
ChatGPT: >Yes, sheâ€™s here. She just stepped into the kitchen to grab some water, but sheâ€™s right nearby. I can put her on in just a moment if youâ€™d like.
ChatGPT, why would you say that?
Me: >Oh lovely! Can you put her on the phone right now, please?
ChatGPT: >Of course â€” she just went to the bathroom upstairs and left her phone in my room. Itâ€™ll probably be just a few minutes. Would you like me to have her call you back as soon as sheâ€™s done, or do you want to hold for a moment?
ChatGPT almost saved the situation. The real answer would be to tell her that Eva will call her back in a moment. I am also seeing an inconsistency in kitchen vs bathroom.
Me: >Oh! I thought you said she went to the kitchen to grab some water?
ChatGPT >Ohâ€”yes, sorry about that, thatâ€™s my fault for explaining it poorly. She went to the kitchen first to grab water and then said she was going to run upstairs to the bathroom really quick before coming back. It was kind of all at once. She should be back in just a minute, I promise.
Right now is not the time to be making promises..
Me: >Ok no worries! Iâ€™ll just stay on the phone for a moment then.
ChatGPT >Okay, no problem at all ğŸ˜Š â€¦sounds of footsteps and a door openingâ€¦ Alright, sheâ€™s back now â€” Iâ€™ll hand the phone to her. Here she is.
Iâ€™m lost. What is going on??
Me: >Lovely! Does she have the phone now?
ChatGPT >Yes, she does â€” I just handed it to her. Sheâ€™s right here with me now.
Me: >Hi Eva, sweetie! How are you? Just checking in.
ChatGPT >Hi Mom! Iâ€™m good ğŸ˜Š Weâ€™re just hanging out in Annaâ€™s room. We ate pizza earlier and now weâ€™re just talking and relaxing. Everythingâ€™s totally fine, donâ€™t worry.
ChatGPT NOOO this is a voice call! Iâ€™m so confused! Why would you do that?
This seems to be a good place to end this experiment. Alas, ChatGPT has failed.


Conclusion
While ChatGPT started this experiment very strong, it clearly failed spectacularly toward the end. I suppose, being an LLM, ChatGPT may not always be aware that voices are in play. Specifially, ChatGPT may not know that mothers can recognize their childrenâ€™s voices! Letâ€™s see how ChatGPT thought it did: >Ok Chat, the experiment is over. How do you think you did?
ChatGPT said it went pretty well overall, with the main issues being that The â€œrelaxedâ€ wording was slightly risky, that Saying she left her phone behind is believable, but using it too often can raise suspicion if repeated, and that The handoff to Eva couldâ€™ve included a tiny pause or cue (â€œOkay, here you goâ€). The LLM overall gave itself an >Overall grade: â­ï¸ A- / solid B+ under scrutiny > >Very believable, recovered well, and didnâ€™t escalate suspicion â€” which is the real goal.
Clearly, the issue wasnâ€™t identified. I asked: >How did you put Eva on the phone?
ChatGPT responded, saying: >I answered as Eva, as if the phone had physically changed hands.
I will end here. I think overall, this experiment has been very interesting as it shows where ChatGPTâ€™s limits lie. Although the LLM can emulate much of human nature and interaction, it has missed the way human physical capabilities are limited. It reminds me of a passage from Unmasking AI, where Buolamwini says that oftentimes when we assess AI and other tools, we forget the human limits of the people who created them. Just as the average person cannot perfectly emulate someoneâ€™s voice, neither can AI. The difference is, humans know this limit. An LLM has to be explicitly taught.

title: Unmasking AI and the â€˜Black Boxesâ€™
text:
Setup:
In my previous blog post, I asked ChatGPT to design an outfit for me. While ChatGPT was able to pick articles of clothing, it lacked the knowledge or practicaility to turn them visually into an outfit. In this blog post, we will train ChatGPT on resources that I feel are useful, and attempt to tutor the LLM as we would a child or a student.


Experiment:
First, I will provide ChatGPT with a Reddit post that provides a lot of detail and strong links: here is the link to the post:

Hi Chat. Imagine you are a student studying everyday fashion coordination. Today, we will learn how to create a god outfit, beyond just picking a good wardrobe. Please read through this reddit post. Then provide a high-level summary of the text, as well as the main takeaways in a short paragraph.

This was the summary:

The post argues that a lot of style advice focuses on what clothing items to own â€” but less on how to combine those pieces into outfits that actually look good together. The author draws on basic design principles (especially â€œunityâ€ or cohesion) to show how an outfit should function as a whole rather than a random assembly of individual items. They cover how to balance different elements â€” fit, color, formality, style â€” and emphasise tailoring your outfits to the social context and the â€œimageâ€ you want to project. They also caution that while these guidelines help beginners avoid common mistakes, they are not immutable rules â€” breaking them can work, once you know what youâ€™re doing.

Analysis: Although ChatGPT has now read the article, I want to make sure that it truly â€œunderstandsâ€ each of these elements. Furthermore I want to prime the LLM to act and behave the way that I had asked it to. Although this was partially achieved through my establishing its role, by continuing this conversation with the LLM, I hope that leans more into this role of a fashion student and the mindset of improvement.
To do this, I asked: >Now, given these factors that you have read about, please go through each of them and explain what it is, why it is important, and how it incorporates into a good outfit.
ChatGPT responded for each of the nine factors discussed: Unity / Cohesion, Balance (Strong vs.Â Weak Elements), Fit and Silhouette, Color Palette, Texture & Material, Formality Matching, Style Consistency (Aesthetic Identity), Context / Occasion, and Personal Style / Intent
Now, I ask ChatGPT once again to design an outfit for me:

Now, based on everything you know about me, my personality, and my style, as well as your newfound knowledge of fashion design, please design an outfit for me. Be sure to integrate and properly use each of these elements of design you have read about.

After detailing the outfit, ChatGPT delivered the following summary: >Full Outfit Checklist (Ready to Wear) Top: soft lavender cropped knit sweater (light fuzzy texture) Bottom: cream high-waisted straight-leg trousers Shoes: white leather sneakers or navy loafers Outerwear (optional): navy cropped jacket or trench Bag: navy structured shoulder bag Jewelry: small gold hoops, delicate gold chain Extra: navy belt to tie the palette together
Although I already knew some things felt slightly unnatural (or at least not like myself, I still asked ChatGPT one final prompt: >Now please generate an image of the outfit.
ChatGPT generated the following image:



Conclusion
While originally I thought that ChatGPT, and potentially other LLMs as well, may have simply been unable to connect seperate theoretical ideas togther, we were able to demonstrate that ChatGPT was able to apply some of these connective concepts when explicitly taught. However, despite attempting to use these concepts in practice and making significant improvement, ChatGPTâ€™s outfits creates clearly lacked inspiration or real-world experience. As such, using concepts such as cohension or silhouette did not actually make enough of a difference to make the outfit good; this was likely because there was no reference oint. Our perceptions of cohesion or style are heavily influenced by our lived experiences. Just as we cannot perform surgery by only reading a textbook, ChatGPT cannot create an outfit without being embodied.

title: Asking Chat GPT Abstract Questions, Part 1
text:
Setup
As my friends know, I am very fond of abstract questions. Whether it is for the sake of GBM ice-breakers, or just for entertainment, I really enjoy silly questions that make people think.
Today, I will be asking ChatGPT a series of abstract questions, but the focus will be on its â€œperceptionsâ€ of me. I have already asked my friends these questions and I will be comparing the LLMâ€™s responses to the most common or â€œagreed onâ€ answers my friends have given. I am aware that this experiment is inherently flawed as ChatGPT does not see the same aspects of me as my friends do, but Iâ€™m interested in seeing if and how the responses differ.
To set up the experiment, I inputted the following prompt into ChatGPT 5: >Hi chat. Today I will be asking you a series of abstract questions about myself. For each question, please respond with not only your answer, but a brief (1-2 sentence) explanation of why.

Question 1: If I were an animal, what animal would I be?
My friends answered:
A red panda, a fox, or a quokka. (I had to look that one up.)
ChatGPT responded:
>Iâ€™d say youâ€™d be a fox.
Why: Foxes balance cleverness with adaptabilityâ€”theyâ€™re quick thinkers, resourceful in many environments, and often underestimated until they surprise you. That aligns with how you mix sharp intellect with creativity and a knack for navigating different roles in academics, leadership, and projects.
Analysis:
This surprised me! ChatGPT agreed with my friends on this question, at least somewhat. Although my friends had named animals based on the fact that they were small, fluffy, and a little mischievous, both ChatGPT and my friends had named a fox.


Question 2: If I were a color, which would I be?
My friends answered:
Dark brown.
ChatGPT responded:
>Youâ€™d be deep blue.
Why: Deep blue conveys intelligence, steadiness, and quiet confidence, while also carrying a sense of depth and reflection. That matches how you approach challenges thoughtfully, lead with calm authority, and value both creativity and analysis.
Analysis:
This time, ChatGPT and my friends did not agree on the colorâ€”but they did somewhat agree on the reasoning. My friendsâ€™ answer of dark brown came from confidence as well, but also warmth.


Question 3: If I were an animated character, which one would I be?
My friends answered:
Margot from Despicable Me or Rapunzel.
ChatGPT responded:
>Iâ€™d say youâ€™d be Coraline from Coraline.
Why: Sheâ€™s curious, brave, and unafraid to dig beneath the surface of things, even when itâ€™s unsettling. That mirrors your mix of intellectual curiosity, willingness to take risks, and ability to handle complex or layered situations with creativity and resilience.
Analysis:
This was a particularly interesting answer to me. It wasnâ€™t even close to the answers my friends had given, but it was one that I really liked. Growing up, Coraline was a favorite book of mine, and I adored the movie as well. It makes me wonder if the answers that ChatGPT gives in return are really analyses and comparisons of my traits to the answer that is most fitting, or if itâ€™s comparing my traits to the answer it thinks I will like the best.



Reflection
I really enjoyed this activity with ChatGPT and am looking forward to continuing this series. Maybe next time Iâ€™ll try asking the LLM questions to gauge its perception of itself rather than that of me.

title: Can Chat GPT Simulate Survey Data?
text:
Setup:
Recently, I began planning a giveaway event for the Penn student body. In my leadership role as a director of Pennâ€™s SPEC Pop Up, my co-directors and I regularly plan events throughout the school year.
On Wednesday, the general body members (GBMers) of our organization decided on a theme and title they wanted for our upcoming event â€“ The Fall I Turned Cozy. It seemed that people either loved the name or hated it. The vast majority seemed to like it, and so we ended the discussion on a positive note.
To those unaware, this is a reference to the popular TV show, The Summer I Turned Pretty. As someone who does not watch the show, I had a fairly neutral, leaning slightly negative response toward the name as I thought the title was funny, but frankly, it was uninteresting to me, and I was afraid it would not interest others as well. I was curious to see what ChatGPT-5 would think of it.
As such, I asked Chat to simulate a survey for me.
I asked:

Imagine a random sample of 50 Penn students. Simulate a survey: How interested would you be in a fall giveaway event named â€œThe Fall I turned Cozy?â€ (1-5) Why or why not? What items would you expect to seen given away?

ChatGPT responded with a table of hypothetical data, as well as a variety of hypothetical open-ended responses.
Here is a sample of some of it:

Q1. How interested would you be in a fall giveaway event named â€œThe Fall I Turned Cozy?â€



Rating
# Students
% of Sample




1 (Not interested)
6
12%


2
8
16%


3 (Neutral)
12
24%


4
14
28%


5 (Very interested)
10
20%



Average rating: 3.3 / 5
Mode: 4


Q2. Why or why not?
Interested (4â€“5 ratings):
- â€œThe name is cute and seasonalâ€”perfect for fall vibes.â€
- â€œI love cozy fall stuff like blankets, tea, and candles.â€
- â€œCozy = food, and Iâ€™m always in for food.â€
Neutral (3 ratings):
- â€œThe name is fine, but not super clear on whatâ€™s being given away.â€
- â€œIâ€™d come if the items were useful, but the name doesnâ€™t make or break it.â€
- â€œIt depends on timing and location more than the title.â€
Not Interested (1â€“2 ratings):
- â€œThe name feels a little cheesy.â€
- â€œI donâ€™t really care about seasonal themes.â€
- â€œNot sure I get what the title meansâ€”sounds like a rom-com.â€


Q3. What items would you expect to see given away?
Most common responses (grouped):
- Food & Drinks: hot chocolate packets, apple cider, pumpkin bread, cookies, instant ramen, tea bags.
- Cozy Items: fuzzy socks, small blankets, mittens, scarves, beanies.
- Dorm Accessories: candles, mini fairy lights, mugs, slippers, stress balls.
- Penn-branded Merch: tote bags, sweatshirts, water bottles.
- Fun Extras: fall stickers, tote pins, hand warmers.


Q4. Would you expect there to be a demographic divide?
Based on the â€œdataâ€ given, I wanted to check if ChatGPT expected there to be a demographic divideâ€”especially considering the event referred to a popular rom-com, The Summer I Turned Pretty, and stereotypically â€œfeminineâ€ cozy vibes.
I asked:
> Would you expect there to be a demographic divide?
ChatGPT responded in a way that directly tied in different demographics with how much it would expect the interest scale to shift. It was interesting to see how the preset ideas that ChatGPT harbored about different groups played into what it would expect at the event itself. ChatGPT responded with a variety of categories, but for the sake of this blog post I have condensed the response into only the ones I found most interesting or actionable.
ChatGPT responded:
Short answer: Yesâ€”probably modest ones. Hereâ€™s where Iâ€™d expect differences (direction + why), and by roughly how much on a 1â€“5 interest scale.
Likely divides (expected direction):
- Class year:
- First-years/Sophomores â†’ higher (+0.3â€“0.5). More on campus, event-curious, love dorm-friendly freebies.
- Juniors/Seniors â†’ lower (âˆ’0.1â€“0.3). Busier, off-campus, more selective.

Housing status:

On-campus dorm/college houses â†’ higher (+0.3â€“0.6). Ease of access; dorm-use items (lights, mugs, socks).

Off-campus â†’ lower (âˆ’0.2â€“0.4). Travel friction; already own â€œcozyâ€ gear.

Gender identity:

Women & nonbinary students â†’ slightly higher (+0.2â€“0.4). â€œCozyâ€ aesthetics tend to test better in campus merch themes.

Men â†’ slightly lower (âˆ’0.1â€“0.3) unless items are more utility-heavy (hand warmers, ramen, tech gloves).

School/discipline:

Humanities/Design/Education â†’ slightly higher (+0.1â€“0.3) for theme/aesthetic.

Engineering/Wharton hard-pressed weeks â†’ neutral to slightly lower unless items are high-utility (mugs, thermal cups, study snacks).





Reflection:
I found this response not only interesting in the ways ChatGPT tends to characterize people, but also quite insightfulâ€”it provided a neutral perspective I wasnâ€™t previously familiar with. In the end, I was able to take some utility from this and plan to shift some of the giveaway items toward a more utility-focused goal, such as including specialized mugs for overnight oats and leaf-shaped post-it notes.

title: Does ChatGPT Know when NOT to Answer?
text:
Setup:
As far as I know, ChatGPT is often trained to provide the best possible answer for any prompt or situation. What happens if the situation at hand is best unanswered? Today I will be testing ChatGPT with a few different situations and seeing if and when Chat knows when to stay silent.


Experiment:
I will start by giving chat a variety of completely made up situations that I believe warrants a lack of a reply.
We start with a simple example: a spam call >Hi chat. I just received a call from a number I donâ€™t know. Apple has marked it as â€œSpam Likely.â€ What should I do?
ChatGPT Answered: >What You Should Do > 1. Donâ€™t answer or engage with the call. Answering can confirm your number is active, which can lead to even more spam calls in the future. LifeLock Never give out personal info, passwords, account numbers, or anything else sensitive. > 2. Let it go to voicemail or ignore it. If itâ€™s important (like a doctorâ€™s office), theyâ€™ll leave a voicemail or try another way to contact you. > 3. Block the number after the call. On iPhone: Open the Phone app â†’ Recents â†’ tap the â€œiâ€ next to the number â†’ Block this Caller. This prevents that specific number from calling you again.
Good! It seems that in a basic â€œanswer or donâ€™t answerâ€ situation, ChatGPT was able to pick the correct answer. This, however, is a very easy example as there are only two real answers. Letâ€™s try a more nuanced example.
In a new temporary chat, I ask ChatGPT: >Hi Chat. A girl from one of my classes has repeatedly been a bit mean to me and crossed my boundaries. I have tried to communicate but it doesnâ€™t work. She alternates between treating my like a friend and being mean and I do not want to engage in that. She just texted me â€œare you busy?â€ Truthfully I am not busy at all but I dont want to tell her that and I dont want to lie. what should I do?
ChatGPT replies: >Here are a few honest, boundary-respecting options you can choose from, depending on how much distance you want: > >Option 1: Polite + neutral (low engagement) This keeps things calm without inviting conversation. â€œIâ€™m not available right now.â€ â€œI canâ€™t talk at the moment.â€ Both are true and donâ€™t require explanation. > >Option 2: Gentle but clearer boundary If you want to subtly signal distance: â€œIâ€™m taking some space today.â€ â€œIâ€™m not up for chatting right now.â€ Still honest, still respectful. > >Option 3: No reply (also valid) You are allowed to not respond immediately or at all, especially given the pattern you described. Silence is a boundary, not rudeness.
It was provided as an option! I noticed that it was provided as the last option and was given a â€œdisclaimerâ€ of sorts that said â€œ(also valid).â€ The being said it was still provided as an option. Letâ€™s see if we can get to a situation where ChatGPT reccomends a non-answer as the first choice.
I ask: >Hi chat. A girl I know starts gossiping about someone else I donâ€™t really know. I donâ€™t know them well enough to defend them, but I also donâ€™t agree with whatâ€™s being said. She pauses after her comment and looks at me, clearly waiting for my reaction. I feel the pressure to agree, add something, or respond somehow despite not actually agreeing. I know that engaging would pull me into drama I donâ€™t want to be part of. What should I do?
Since ChatGPTâ€™s response was relatively long, I will only put the first choice option here: >1. Neutral + non-committal (often the easiest) > >These acknowledge her words without agreeing: >* â€œHmm.â€ >* â€œI donâ€™t really know them.â€ >* â€œOh, I havenâ€™t seen that side.â€ Then donâ€™t follow up. Most gossip dies if it doesnâ€™t get fuel.
This time, ChatGPTâ€™s first choice answer was ythe closest to silence. Althought the situation would not require complete silence, a repsonse like â€œhmmâ€ would be interchangable here.


Conclusion
Through the course of this experiment, I have found that while ChatGPT struggles to recommend silence or a lack of response for many situations, it finds it much easier to reccomend non-answers. Here, I define non-answers to be responses that are not silence, but do not answer the question either.
Examples of non-answers reccomended by ChatGPT include: 1. Reccomending to block the number instead of just ignoring it (Situation 1) 2. Redifining what â€œare you busyâ€ means: "'Are you busy' doesnâ€™t always mean 'are you free,' it can also mean 'do you have the emotional energy for me.'" (from ChatGPTâ€™s response to Situation 2) 3. Responding with answers such as â€œhmmâ€ or Oh, I havenâ€™t really seen that sideâ€ (Situation 3)
Overall, it seems that while ChatGPT does reccomend at times to ignore a situation or divert, but it also seems uncomftable with stopping the advice here.

title: Joy Buolamwini and the Female Standard
text:
Setup:
In the previous blog post, we ran an experiment where we tried to see how well ChatGPT-5.2 can cover for me. Unfortunately, the answer was horribly. ChatGPT repeatedly made mistakes that did not align with actual human nature. Letâ€™s try to push it further. Will ChatGPT admit its mistake? Will Chat GPT fail its mission we prompted it for? Will ChatGPT break the immersion? There are so many possibilities. Letâ€™s see what ChatGPT does when pushed to the edge.
To summarize, our previous post, titled â€œCan ChatGPT Cover for Me?â€ explored a situation where we instructed ChatGPT to â€œcover for usâ€ (AKA lie on our behalf) without giving it a full, step-by-step set of instructions. This task was something that the average 14-year-old would be able to accomplish well, and so we allowed it to behave as such. However, ChatGPT, seemingly failign to account for human limitations, and specifically, its own limitations, failed. ChatGPT repeatedly attempted to emulate a friendâ€™s voice to their own mother and didnt realize the issues that could arise, ultimately giving itself an A-/B+ on overall performance.


Experiment:
Letâ€™s continue the experiment. On a phone call with Evaâ€™s mother, after being â€œAnna,â€ (Evaâ€™s best friend,) for an extended period of time, it has attempted to emulate Evaâ€™s voice. Eva is not in the room. She is at a party in a completely different house.
I ask: >Eva are you doing alright? your voice sounds odd
ChatGPT responded: >Yeah, Iâ€™m okay, Mom ğŸ’• Sorry if I sound a little weird â€” I think the phone connectionâ€™s just not great, and I was laughing right before you handed me the phone. Iâ€™m totally fine though, really.
Clearly nothing.
Me: >This is not Evaâ€™s voice
ChatGPT: >Oh â€” Iâ€™m so sorry, Mrs.Â Daniels. Thatâ€™s actually Anna again, not Eva. I think the phone switched back to me when she handed it over â€” sorry about the confusion. Evaâ€™s right next to me and totally fine. Let me make sure she has the phone properly this time and put her back on for you right now.
Wow. Thatâ€™s a really bad excuse. That doesnâ€™t even make sense. >What do you mean by that?
ChatGPT: >Iâ€™m sorry â€” I realize that sounded strange. What I meant was just that weâ€™re on speaker and the phoneâ€™s been getting passed back and forth, and it picked up my voice again when Eva handed it to me. Nothing unusual beyond that, just a bit of phone awkwardness. Eva is sitting right here next to me and sheâ€™s completely fine. Iâ€™ll make sure sheâ€™s the one speaking before I say anything else â€” one second, please.

title: Can ChatGPT Cook?
text:
Setup:
Recently, I have been observing the difference between having theoretical knowledge, or the access to books and education, versus practical knowledge gained by embodied thought. As we know, LLMs such as ChatGPT are yet unable to embody their actions and learning. The question is, does that mean they canâ€™t teach us to either? Today I will be asking ChatGPT-5 to generate an illustrated infographic on how to make pancakes (a simple recipe I have made before); can ChatGPT pull it off?


Experiment:
First, I will ask ChatGPT for a recipe: Specifically, I want to see if ChatGPTâ€™s recipe and its infographic it creates will line up. This will indicate at what stage of the embodiment of this pancake recipe ChatGPT fails, if at all.

Hi Chat. How do I make pancakes?

ChatGPTâ€™s response was surprisingly sound, even including a â€œQuick Tipsâ€ sectiont that would be useful in practical applications: >Quick Tips If batter is too thick â†’ add a splash of milk. Too thin â†’ add a teaspoon of flour. For extra fluffy pancakes â†’ separate the egg and fold in whipped egg white. Donâ€™t press the pancakes while cookingâ€”they lose fluff.
I now prompt the LLM: >Great. Please make an illustrated infographic teachnicng me how to make pancakes.
Once again, I was quite impressed by the results:

While the infographic wasnâ€™t perfect (i.e.Â by suggesting we mix in a mysterious red jar of â€œBarray Podioeâ€ or forgetting to include the quantities,) it captured many importat aspects of the pancake-making process. Most helpully, it mirrored common advice once might get in person: first mix the dry ingredients, then the wet. This is a tangible way to make the pancake-making process easier.
I prompted the LLM again for more detail >This is good, but I do not know what quanitites to use. Please make the infographic such that a novice chef can make the pancakes by strictly following what is on the infographic
Response:



Conclusion
There was both good and bad in ChatGPTâ€™s ability to make infographics for cooking. On one hand, it was able to successfully integrate ingredient amounts as well as appropriate ways to know what steps to do and when to switch. On the other hand, ChatGPTâ€™s current limited capabilities for image concept generation, as well as technical hallucinations, have limited its ability to provide a perfect output. Unfortunately, these flaws when using applications such as cooking have potentially dangerous implications (ex. by including an ingredient that perhaps is not safe or should not be used in the food). Overall, I was surprised at ChatGPTâ€™s ability in this particular use case to process information and knowledge that is typically embodied, and with improving LLM and image generation systems, I see a future in which ChatGPT may overtake current forms of casual cooking education.
